licence.p: The transcription of this work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. NEED TO INCLUDE COPYRIGHT BLOCK FOR ADDITIONAL 29729

title.title: The Minor Poems of John Lydgate
Edited from all Available MSS., with an Attempt to Establish the Lydgate Canon

zone.line: Nowe feloweth here the maner of a bille by weye
of supplycation put to the kynge holding his noble
fest of crystmasse in the castell of hartford as in
dysguysinge of þe rude vpplandishe people complayninge
on hir wyues / with the boystrus answere of thiyr
wyues / deuysed by lidgate / at þe requeste of the
count rouolore / Brys slayn at louiers
Most noble prynce with support of your grace
ther bene entred in to your royall place
and lettTrinity R.3.20 has "late" here. comen in to your castell
your pore leges which like nothinge well
now in the begyninge of this newe yeare
certayne swaynes full froward of ther chere

of entent comen fallen on ther kneThere is an "a" next to "of" in the left hand margin of this line. Based on other examples, in particular the Add. 29729 edition of the Mumming at Eltham, this would indicate a mistake that the scribe is correcting for, but no mistake is actually present.

ffor to compleyne vnto your magestieThe letter "b" is struck through in the left hand margin of this paragraph. This may be an indicator of a nota mark, as occurs in Trinity R.3.20 and later in this witness, or a carryover from the exemplar since the Trinity nota mark is also different from other examples in that witness.
vpon the mescheffe of great aduersyte
vpon the trouble and the cruellte
whych that they haue endued in there lyves
by the felnesse of ther ferce wyves
whych is a turmente very inportable
A bond of sorowe / a knott vnneuiable
ffor who is bound / or loked in maryage
yff he be ould / he falleth in dotage
and yonge folkes of ther lymes skender
grene and lusty / and of braune but tender
phylosophers callen in such age

a chuld to wyue / a wodnesse or a rageThere is what appears to be an "a" to the left of the final line in the verse. Much like the previous section that is likely meant to be a nota mark misinterpreted by the scribe.
ffor they afferme / ther is non erthly stryffe
may be compared / to weddynge of a wyffe
and who that euer standeth in the case
he with his rebecke / may singe full oft allas
lyke as thos hynes / here standenge on by on
he maye with them vpon the daunce goon
learne the tras / both at euen and morow
of karycantowe / in torment and in sorowe
weyle the whyll ellas that he was borne
for obbeThe scribe has bracketed on three sides the underlined word here, rather than simply underlining it. They are inconsistent in their practice. the reve / that goth here all to forne
he playneth sore / his mariage is not mekeThis differs from Trinity R.3.20 and thus from MacCraken, where it is rendered as "meete."
ffor hys wyff beautryce Bitterswett
cast vpon him an hougly chere full rowghe
whan he comeeth home / full wery from the ploughe
with hugely sherecke / dead and pale of chere
In hope to fynde redy his dynner
demonstrando vj rusticul

¶than sitteth Beautryce bollinge at the noalleFrom this point on in the witness the scribe follows what is likely the practice of the exemplar and places an "n" to the left of the opening line denoting a new section.
As she that geueth of hym no maner talle
ffor she alldaye with hyr Iouose nolle
hath for the collyk pouped in the bolle
¶And for fede ache / with peper and ginger
grinke dolled alle / to make histhrot cler
And kometh he hom / whan hit draweth to eve
and than robyn / the cely pour reve
ffynd none amendes of harme ne damage
but benegrowell and soupeth cold potage
and of his wyffe hath non other cher
but cokkutwortes vnto his supper
this is hys seruyce sittynge at the borde
and cely robyn yf he spoake aword
beautryce of him / doth so lyttell rekke
that with hir distaffe / she hitteth hym in þe nekk
ffor a medecyne to chaffe with his blud
with such a medcyneTrinity R.3.20 has "metyerde" here. / she hath shape him a hud
¶and colyn cobeller / folowinge his felowe
hath had his parte of the sam lawe
ffor by þe fayth þat the prest him gaffe
his wyffe hath taugħt hym to play at the stafe
hir quarter stroke / were so large and round
that on his rigge the towche was allweyes found
demonstrando
pictaciarium
¶cely sourechere / his owen precyous spouse
koude hym rehete whan he came to house
yf he ought spake whan he fellte payne
agayne one word allwaye he had twayne
she quyte hym euer / ther was nothynge to seche
six for one / of wordes and strokes eche
ther was no men / betwen them for to gone
what euer he wan cloutyng ould shone
the werke daye playnly this is no tale
she would on sundaye drynke it at þe aleTrinity R.3.20 has "nale" here instead. Ale makes better sense in terms of the narrative of the mumming.
his part was none, he sayd not once naye
it is no game but on herenest playe
ffor lacke of wit a man his wyffe to greue
thos husbandmen / who so would them leue
kould yf they dyrst tell In audyence
what foloweth ther of wyues to done offence
is non so ould ne ryuell on hur face
with tonge or staffe but þat she dothTrinity R.3.20 has "dare" here. manasse
mabylle god hur saue and blesse
Koude yff hir list / bere here of wytnesse
wordes strockes / vnhappye and harde grace
with sharpe nayles kracchynge in þe face
I meane thus whan the distaffe is broke
with ther fystes wyues wylle wroke
¶blessed the men / that cane in such offence
mekely suffer / take all in pacyence
tender such wyfely pulgatory
heuen for ther mede to raygne ther in glorye
god graunt all husbandys that be in this place
to wyn so heuen / for his holy grace
¶next in order / thys bocher stoute and bould
that killed hath / bulles and bores olde
rhia bartellniew / for all his brod knyffe
yet durst he neuer with his sturdy wyffe
in no mater holde champartye
and yff he did / she wolde anon defye

his pompeThis looks, at first glance, like "un" rather than "m' based on the number of possible minims. Comparison with other "p" glyphs in this manuscript, however, show that the scribe consistently begins the p with a mark to the left of the initial descenter. Thus, what the scribe is doing is completing the m, then carrying the stroke up to the initial position of the following "p." A similar upstroke after the final minim can be seen in "hym" in the following line. his pryd with a sterne thought
and sodenly setten hym at nought
though his bely were rounded lyche an ocke
she would not fayle / to gyue the fyrst stroke
for proude pernelle / lyche a campyon
wolde leue hir puddinges / in agreat cawdron
suffer them boylle / and take of them non hede
but with hir skumer reche hym on the heued
she was no cowarde found at suche a nede
hir fyst fułł oft made his chekes bled
what quarell euer that he agaynst hyr sett
she cast hyr not / to dye in his debte
she made no talle / but gwytt hym by and by
his quarter sowde / she payde hym faythfully
and his wagis with all hur beste entente
she made ther of no assyne ment
¶Seke thome tinker / with all his pannes olde
and alle the wynes of banbury that he solde
his fryth hys hamour hys bagge portatyffe
bare vp his arme / when he foughte with his wyffe
he founde for haft ne better bokeler
vponn his cheke / the distaffe cam so nere
demonstrando
the tynker
His name was cleped tybet tapister
to brawle and broylle / she made ne maner fer
to chakke his pilche / stoundemell now and thanne
thikker than thome / koude clowten any panne
¶next Colle tyler / full heuy of his chere
complaynetħ on phelyce / his wyffe the wafurer
all hys bred witħ suger nys not bake
yit on his chekis / sometyme he hath a aake
so hat and newe or he can taken heed
that his eares glowe verrye red
ffor a medycyne whan the frost is cold
makinge his teth to ratell that bene ould
¶this is the complaynte / that thos dastardes colde
make on ther wyues that byne so stoute and bould
thos holy / marturs preued full pacyente
lowly besechynge / in all ther best entente
vnto your nobell royall magesty
to graunt them fraunchyse and also liberte
sith they be fetered / and bounden in maryage
a saffeconndyte to saufe them from domage
eke vnder support / of your hygh renowme
graunt them also / a proteccyon
¶conquest of wyues / is rone througħ this land
cleyminge of ryght to haue þe higher hand
but yff ye lust of your regollye
the ould testament for to modefye
¶and that the list / asselen ther request
that thos poure husbandes might liue in rest
and that ther wyues / in ther fell might
woll medle amonge mercy withther ryght
ffor it cam neuer of natur ne reson
alyonesse to oppres þe lyon
¶nor a woulfse for all hur tyrany
ouer the wouffe to haue the mastrye
ther byn now wollffes / mo than two or thre
the rokes record / whych þat younder be
soth to this mater / of mercy and of grace
and or thos dasters parte out of this place

line.note: Line seven has been inserted in the right hand margin, with a line indicating its placement after the previous line. This is different structurally from the marginal "directions" that occur throughout, and so has been added to the TEI here rather than in the marginal section following.

zone.line: or they be likely to stand in Iapardye
It is no game with wyues for to playe
but for foles / that giue no force to dye
i distaues
¶ take hede of the aunswer of the wyues
¶touchynge the substaunce of this hygh discord
we six wyues / bene full of on accorde
yff word and chydinge / may vs not avaylle
we woll dryte it in Champoloos by batayll
Imparte / oure righte / laate or elles rathe
and for oure partye / the worthy wyffe of bathe
cane showe statutes / mo than six or seuen
how wyues / make ther husbandis wynne heuen
maugre the fende and all his vyolence
ffor ther bertu / of parfyte pacyence
parteyneth to wyues now adayes
saufe on ther husbandes for to make assays
ther pacyence was buryed longe ago
gresyldes story recoreth pleynly so
it longeth to vs / to clappen all a myll
no counsayll kepe / but þe truth out tell
we be not borne / by heuenly Influence
of our nature to kepe vs in sylence
for this is no doute / euery prudent wyffe
hath redy aunswere / in all suche maner stryfe
though thos dotardes / with ther dokked berdes
whycħ straneth oute / as they were made of herdes
haue agayne vs / agrett quarell now sette
I trowe the bakoun / was neuer of him fette
A waye at dounmarwe / in the pryorye
they wene of vs to haue ay the mastrye
elles thos foles / let them aunswere here to
who can them washe / who can them wringe also
wrynge them theTrinity R.3.20 has "ye", as does the EETS edition based on it. It seems likely that the scribe has misread their exemplar, assuming that a y is a thorn. wrynge / so als god vs sped
till that some tyme / we make ther nosis bled
and sowe ther clothes when they be to rente
and cloute ther bacckes till som of vs be shent
lo yet thos foles god gyne them sorowe chaunce
wolle sett ther wyues / vnder gouernaunce
make vs to them / for to lowte lowe
we know to well the bout of Iackes bowe
all that we clayme / we clayme it but of ryte
yf they say nay let preue it out by fyght
we woll vs ground not vppon womanhede
ffye on them cowardes / when it cometh to nede
we clayme mastry / by prescryption
be longe tytell of successyon
ffrom wyffe to wyffe which we will not lesse
Men maye well gruge / but they shall not chese
custome is vs for nature and vsaunce
to let oure husbandes / lyfe in great noysaunce
humbely besechynge nowe at on worde
vnto oure lege / and most souerain lorde
vs to defend of his regallye
and of his grace / sustenen our partye
requirynge the statute of olde antiquyte
that in your tyme / it maye confermed be
¶the complaynte of the lewd husbandis with the cruell
aunswers of ther wyues / hard the kynge and gaue
ther vponn sentence and Iudgemente
¶This noble prynce most royall of estate
hauynge an eyeghe / to this mortall debate
ffirst aduertyinge / of full hygħ prudence
wyll vnavysed gyue here no sentence
with oute counsaylle / of haste to procede
by sodeyne dome / for he taketh heede
to eyther partye / at Iuge in differente
seinge the paryll / of hasty Iudgmente
pourposith him / in this contynued stryffe
to gyue no sentence ther of diffynytyue
til ther be made examynaciony
of other partye and Inquysiciouny
he considereth / and maketh raysoun his guyd
as egall Iudge enclyninge to no syde
not with standynge he hath compassyony
of the poure husbandes trybulaccyon
sso offt arrested / with ther wyues rokes
which of there distaues / haue so many knokes
paysinge also in his regallye
the lawe þat wemen alegge for ther partye
custome nature and ekk prescriptiony
statute vsed / by confirmacyouny
processe and date of tyme out of mynd
recorde of cronycles witnesse of ther kynd
wherfore þe kynge / woll all this next yeare
that wyues franchyse stand hole and entyre
and that no man with stand it ne wyth drawe
till man may fynde sume processe out by lawe
that they shuld by nature in ther lyues
haue souerayntee / on ther prudente wyues
athinge vnkouthe / which was neuer found
let men be ware ther fore / or they be bound
the bond is hard / who so that loketh well
somman were leuer fettred be in stell
raunsom migħt helpe / his peyne to aswaage
but who is wedded / lyueth / euer in seruage
And I know neuer no wher for ner nere
man that was glad / to bynd hym prysonere
though that his prysom his castell or his holde
were depeynted with asure or with golde
¶Explicete
